subsection.content: An authorized institution must not, according to the due diligence performed by it on an exposure, allocate to the exposure a risk-weight that is lower than the exposure’s rating-based RW.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (2) does not apply to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: sovereign exposures; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: public sector entity exposures.

subsection.leadIn: Despite the requirements of this Division, the Monetary Authority may, by written notice given to one or more authorized institutions, require the institution to allocate to an exposure, or exposures belonging to a class of exposure, a risk-weight specified in the notice, if the Monetary Authority considers that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the exposure or the class has, or could reasonably be construed as potentially having, adverse impacts on the financial soundness of the institution; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: flexibility in the capital treatment of the class is necessary or expedient for supporting the economy or maintaining the stability and effective working of the financial system of Hong Kong.

subsection.content: An authorized institution must comply with the requirements of a notice given to it under subsection (5).

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: base risk-weight (基準風險權重)—(a)in relation to a multilateral development bank exposure or unspecified multilateral body exposure, means any risk-weight specified in column 3 of Table 2B;(b)in relation to a bank exposure or qualifying non-bank financial institution exposure, means any risk-weight specified in column 3 of Table 3;(c)in relation to an eligible covered bond exposure, means any risk-weight specified in column 3 of Table 4B or column 3 of Table 4C; and(d)in relation to a general corporate exposure or a specialized lending, means any risk-weight specified in column 3 or 4 of Table 5.

section.name: s54D
section.heading: Mapping ECAI rating to credit quality grade

subsection.content: For the purpose of determining the risk-weight attributable to an exposure that falls within one of the ECAI ratings based portfolios and that is not an unrated exposure, an authorized institution must determine the credit quality grade applicable to the exposure in accordance with this section and sections 54E and 54F.

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an exposure is a sovereign exposure, a multilateral development bank exposure that is not eligible for a risk-weight of 0%, an unspecified multilateral body exposure, a bank exposure, an eligible covered bond exposure, a qualifying non-bank financial institution exposure (QNBFI exposure), a general corporate exposure to a corporate incorporated outside the home jurisdictions of Type B ECAIs or a specialized lending; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: there is a long-term ECAI issue specific rating assigned to the exposure by a Type A ECAI,

subsection.continued: an authorized institution must determine the credit quality grade applicable to the exposure by mapping the long-term ECAI issue specific rating of the exposure to a credit quality grade in accordance with the LT ECAI rating mapping table for Type A ECAIs.

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an exposure is a bank exposure, a QNBFI exposure, a general corporate exposure to a corporate incorporated outside the home jurisdictions of Type B ECAIs or a specialized lending; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: there is a short-term ECAI issue specific rating assigned to the exposure by a Type A ECAI,

subsection.continued: an authorized institution must determine the credit quality grade applicable to the exposure by mapping the short-term ECAI issue specific rating of the exposure to a credit quality grade in accordance with the ST ECAI rating mapping table for Type A ECAIs.

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an exposure is a general corporate exposure to a corporate incorporated in the home jurisdiction of a Type B ECAI; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: there is a long-term ECAI issue specific rating or short-term ECAI issue specific rating assigned to the exposure by a Type A ECAI or that Type B ECAI,

subsection.continued: an authorized institution must determine the credit quality grade applicable to the exposure by mapping the rating of the exposure to a credit quality grade in accordance with the LT ECAI rating mapping table or the ST ECAI rating mapping table, as the case requires, applicable to the ECAI that assigns the rating.

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: there is no long-term ECAI issue specific rating assigned to the exposure by any Type A ECAI; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a Type A ECAI has assigned an ECAI issuer rating to the obligor in respect of the exposure or a long-term ECAI issue specific rating (reference rating) to any other exposure to the obligor,

subsection.continued: an authorized institution must determine the credit quality grade applicable to the exposure by mapping the ECAI issuer rating of the obligor or the reference rating, as the case may be, to a credit quality grade in accordance with the LT ECAI rating mapping table for Type A ECAIs.

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
b
c
paragraph.content: a Type A ECAI has assigned an ECAI issuer rating to the obligor in respect of the exposure or a long-term ECAI issue specific rating (reference rating) to any other exposure to the obligor,

subsection.continued: an authorized institution must determine the credit quality grade applicable to the exposure by mapping the ECAI issuer rating of the obligor or the reference rating, as the case may be, to a credit quality grade in accordance with the LT ECAI rating mapping table for Type A ECAIs.

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an exposure is a general corporate exposure to a corporate incorporated in the home jurisdiction of a Type B ECAI;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: there is neither a long-term ECAI issue specific rating nor a short-term ECAI issue specific rating assigned to the exposure by any ECAI; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a Type A ECAI or the Type B ECAI referred to in paragraph (a) has assigned an ECAI issuer rating to the corporate or a long-term ECAI issue specific rating (reference rating) to any other exposure to the corporate,

subsection.continued: an authorized institution must determine the credit quality grade applicable to the exposure by mapping the ECAI issuer rating of the corporate or the reference rating, as the case may be, to a credit quality grade in accordance with the LT ECAI rating mapping table applicable to the ECAI that assigns the rating.

subsection.leadIn: If an exposure is a public sector entity exposure (PSE exposure) (including a PSE exposure to a sovereign foreign public sector entity), an authorized institution must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: map the ECAI issuer rating assigned to the sovereign of the jurisdiction in which the public sector entity is incorporated to a credit quality grade in accordance with the LT ECAI rating mapping table for Type A ECAIs; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: regard the credit quality grade so obtained as the credit quality grade applicable to the PSE exposure.

subsection.content: For the purpose of determining whether a multilateral development bank exposure is eligible for a risk-weight of 0%, an authorized institution must determine the credit quality grade applicable to the exposure by mapping the ECAI issuer rating of the multilateral development bank concerned to a credit quality grade in accordance with the LT ECAI rating mapping table for Type A ECAIs.

section.name: s54E
section.heading: Application of ECAI ratings

subsection.content: This section applies to the use of ECAI ratings by an authorized institution under this Part for determining the risk-weight attributable to an exposure (however described) (exposure A) that falls within one of the ECAI ratings based portfolios.

subsection.leadIn: In complying with the requirements of section 54D, the institution must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if exposure A has only 1 ECAI issue specific rating—use that rating;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if exposure A has 2 ECAI issue specific ratings that would map into different credit quality grades under that section and result in the allocation of different risk-weights to exposure A under the relevant section in relation to exposure A—use the rating that would result in the allocation of the higher of those risk-weights; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: if exposure A has 3 or more ECAI issue specific ratings—refer to the 2 ratings that would, under that section, map into credit quality grades the use of which would result in the allocation of the lowest risk-weights to exposure A under the relevant section in relation to exposure A, and—

subparagraph.content: if the 2 lowest risk-weights are the same, use any one of the 2 ratings; or
if the 2 lowest risk-weights are different, use the rating that would result in the allocation of the higher of those 2 risk-weights.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsections (5) and (6), if exposure A does not have an ECAI issue specific rating and the obligor in respect of exposure A does not have an ECAI issuer rating but there is a reference exposure, in complying with the requirements of section 54D the institution must determine the rating to be used as follows—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the long-term ECAI issue specific rating of the reference exposure is a low quality rating, the institution may use that long-term ECAI issue specific rating if exposure A ranks equally with, or is subordinated to, the reference exposure in respect of payment or repayment;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the long-term ECAI issue specific rating of the reference exposure is a high quality rating, the institution may use that long-term ECAI issue specific rating if exposure A ranks equally with, or senior to, the reference exposure in respect of payment or repayment.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (5), if exposure A does not have an ECAI issue specific rating and the obligor in respect of exposure A has an ECAI issuer rating but there is no reference exposure, in complying with the requirements of section 54D the institution must determine the rating to be used as follows—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: if the ECAI issuer rating is a low quality rating, the institution may use that ECAI issuer rating if—

subparagraph.content: exposure A ranks equally with, or is subordinated to, the unsecured exposures referred to in subparagraph (i);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: subject to paragraph (c), if the ECAI issuer rating is a high quality rating, the institution may use that ECAI issuer rating if—

subparagraph.content: exposure A is not subordinated to other exposures to that obligor;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: if the ECAI issuer rating is a high quality rating that only applies to a specific exposure class, the institution may use that ECAI issuer rating if—

subparagraph.content: exposure A is in that exposure class;
that rating is only applicable to unsecured exposures to the obligor as an issuer that are not subordinated to other exposures to that obligor in that exposure class; and
exposure A is not subordinated to other exposures to the obligor in that exposure class.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (6), if exposure A is of a kind referred to in subsection (3) and the reference exposure has more than one long-term ECAI issue specific rating, or is of a kind referred to in subsection (4) and the obligor in respect of exposure A has more than one ECAI issuer rating, in complying with the requirements of section 54D, the institution must determine the rating to be used as follows—

paragraph.name: a
b
c
paragraph.content: if it is determined under paragraph (a) that 2 long-term ECAI issue specific ratings or 2 ECAI issuer ratings can be used and the use of the 2 ratings would result in the allocation of different risk-weights to exposure A under the relevant section in relation to exposure A—the institution must use the rating that would result in the allocation of the higher of the 2 different risk-weights;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: if it is determined under paragraph (a) that 3 or more ECAI issue specific ratings or 3 or more ECAI issuer ratings can be used and the use of those ratings would result in the allocation of different risk-weights to exposure A under the relevant section in relation to exposure A—the institution must refer to the 2 ratings that would result in the allocation of the lowest risk-weights to exposure A and—

subparagraph.content: if the 2 lowest risk-weights are the same, use any one of the 2 ratings; or
if the 2 lowest risk-weights are different, use the rating that would result in the allocation of the higher of those 2 risk-weights.

subsection.leadIn: If exposure A is of a kind referred to in subsection (3) and there is more than one reference exposure, the institution must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: apply subsection (3) or (5), as the case requires, to each reference exposure, to determine the long-term ECAI issue specific rating to be used for the purposes of paragraph (b); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: apply subsection (2), as if the long-term ECAI issue specific ratings determined under paragraph (a) were those of exposure A, to determine the long-term ECAI issue specific rating to be used for the purpose of complying with the requirements of section 54D.

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: exposure A does not have an ECAI issue specific rating;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the obligor in respect of exposure A has—

subparagraph.content: at least one reference exposure that has one or more long-term ECAI issue specific ratings; and
one or more ECAI issuer ratings; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: the use, in accordance with section 54D and the relevant section in relation to exposure A, of the ratings below would result in the allocation of 2 different risk-weights to exposure A—

subparagraph.content: the long-term ECAI issue specific rating that would be determined under subsection (3), (5) or (6), as the case requires, as if the obligor did not have any ECAI issuer rating; and
the ECAI issuer rating that would be determined under subsection (4) or (5), as the case requires, as if there were no reference exposure,

subsection.continued: the institution may, in complying with the requirements of that section, use the rating that would result in the allocation of the lower of the 2 different risk-weights to exposure A.

subsection.leadIn: In determining the ECAI rating to be used under subsection (3), (4), (5), (6) or (7)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: subject to paragraph (b), the institution—

subparagraph.content: must use ECAI ratings applicable to foreign currency, if available, to the extent that exposure A is denominated in foreign currency;
must use ECAI ratings applicable to local currency, if available, to the extent that exposure A is denominated in local currency; and

subparagraph.leadIn: may use ECAI issuer ratings applicable to foreign currency, if available, to the extent that—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: exposure A is denominated in local currency; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: no ECAI rating applicable to local currency is available;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if exposure A is denominated in a currency different from the local currency of the obligor in respect of exposure A, the institution may use the obligor’s ECAI rating applicable to the obligor’s local currency, if available, for the purpose of—

subparagraph.content: risk-weighting exposure A where exposure A arises from the institution’s participation in an exposure created by a multilateral development bank; or

risk-weighting the credit protection covered portion of exposure A where exposure A is guaranteed by a multilateral development bank against the risk of the obligor not being able to repay exposure A to the institution because of exchange controls of the jurisdiction in which the obligor is located.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: high quality rating (高質素評級), in relation to exposure A, means an ECAI issuer rating assigned to the obligor in respect of exposure A, or a long-term ECAI issue specific rating assigned to a reference exposure to the obligor in respect of exposure A, that, if being used to determine a risk-weight attributable to exposure A in accordance with section 54D and the relevant section in relation to exposure A, would result in the allocation of a risk-weight to exposure A that would be lower than the risk-weight that would be allocated to an unrated exposure to the obligor;

low quality rating (低質素評級), in relation to exposure A, means an ECAI issuer rating assigned to the obligor in respect of exposure A, or a long-term ECAI issue specific rating assigned to a reference exposure to the obligor in respect of exposure A, that, if being used to determine a risk-weight attributable to exposure A in accordance with section 54D and the relevant section in relation to exposure A, would result in the allocation of a risk-weight to exposure A that would be equal to or higher than the risk-weight that would be allocated to an unrated exposure to the obligor;

relevant section (有關條文), in relation to an exposure that belongs to one of the ECAI ratings based portfolios, means the section in this Subdivision that is applicable to the ECAI ratings based portfolio to which the exposure belongs, but excludes sections 59A and 61(3) and (4).

section.name: s54F
section.heading: Further restrictions on use of ECAI ratings

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of this Part—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an authorized institution may use an ECAI rating to determine the risk-weight attributable to its exposure only if the rating takes into account and reflects the entire amount of the exposure with regard to all payments owed to the institution;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: subject to subsection (2), an authorized institution must not use an ECAI rating assigned to a bank or bank exposure that incorporates assumptions of implicit government support unless the bank is a public bank owned by the government concerned; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: subject to subsection (2), any ECAI issuer rating assigned to a bank (other than a public bank owned by a government), and any ECAI issue specific rating assigned to an exposure to such a bank, that incorporates assumptions of implicit government support must be ignored when—

subparagraph.content: determining under section 54E which ECAI rating may be used for the purposes of section 54D; and
determining whether an exposure to such a bank is an unrated exposure for the purposes of this Part.

subsection.content: Despite subsection (1)(b) and (c), an authorized institution may continue to use ECAI ratings that incorporate assumptions of implicit government support for a period of up to 5 years after the commencement date* of this section for the purpose of determining the risk-weights attributable to bank exposures.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: implicit government support (隱性政府支持), in relation to banks incorporated in a jurisdiction, means the notion that the government of that jurisdiction would act to prevent bank creditors from incurring losses in the event of a bank default or bank distress.

section.name: s55
section.heading: Sovereign exposures

subsection.leadIn: Subject to section 56, an authorized institution must allocate a risk-weight to a sovereign exposure that has been assigned a credit quality grade under section 54D(2) or (5) in accordance with Table 2.

subsection.content: Subject to section 56, an authorized institution must allocate a risk-weight of 100% to a sovereign exposure that is an unrated exposure.

section.name: s56
section.heading: Exceptions to section 55

subsection.content: If a sovereign exposure is a domestic currency exposure to the Government (including an exposure to the Exchange Fund), an authorized institution may allocate a risk-weight of 0% to the exposure.

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a sovereign exposure is a domestic currency exposure to a sovereign (other than the Government or a restricted sovereign); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the relevant banking supervisory authority for the jurisdiction of the sovereign would permit banks incorporated in that jurisdiction to allocate a risk-weight to the exposure that is lower than the risk-weight that would be allocated under section 55 to the exposure,

subsection.continued: an authorized institution may allocate the lower risk-weight to the exposure.

subsection.content: If a sovereign exposure is an exposure to a relevant international organization, an authorized institution may allocate a risk-weight of 0% to the exposure.

section.name: s57
section.heading: Public sector entity exposures

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (3), an authorized institution must allocate a risk-weight to a public sector entity exposure (PSE exposure) that has been assigned a credit quality grade under section 54D(8) in accordance with Table 2A.

subsection.content: If the sovereign of the jurisdiction in which the public sector entity is incorporated does not have an ECAI issuer rating, an authorized institution must allocate a risk-weight of 100% to the exposure.

If a PSE exposure is an exposure to a sovereign foreign public sector entity, section 55, with all necessary modifications, applies to the exposure as if the entity were a sovereign, using the credit quality grade assigned to the PSE exposure under section 54D(8).

section.name: s58
section.heading: Multilateral development bank exposures and unspecified multilateral body exposures

subsection.content: An authorized institution may allocate a risk-weight of 0% to a multilateral development bank exposure (MDB exposure) if the multilateral development bank concerned is assigned a credit quality grade of 1 or 2 under section 54D(9).

subsection.leadIn: If subsection (1) is not applicable to an MDB exposure, an authorized institution must treat the multilateral development bank as if it were an unspecified multilateral body and—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: if the MDB exposure is not an unrated exposure—

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the MDB exposure is an unrated exposure—determine the risk-weight attributable to the exposure in accordance with subsection (4).

subsection.leadIn: Subject to section 54C, an authorized institution must allocate a risk-weight to an unspecified multilateral body exposure that has been assigned a credit quality grade under section 54D(2) or (5) in accordance with Table 2B.

leadIn.b: Risk-weights for Unspecified Multilateral Body Exposures

subsection.content: An authorized institution must allocate a risk-weight of 50% to an unspecified multilateral body exposure that is an unrated exposure.

section.name: s59
section.heading: Bank exposures

subsection.leadIn: This section applies to a bank exposure that is neither of the following exposures—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an unrated exposure to a bank;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an eligible covered bond exposure.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to sections 54C and 59A, if the exposure has been assigned a credit quality grade under section 54D(2) or (6), an authorized institution must allocate a risk-weight to the exposure in accordance with Table 3.

leadIn.b:
Risk-weights for Bank Exposures with Credit Quality
Grades Obtained by Mapping to LT ECAI Rating
Mapping Table for Type A ECAIs

td.p: Risk-weight for short-term bank exposures (other than exposures that have a short-term ECAI issue specific rating)

subsection.leadIn: If the exposure has been assigned a credit quality grade under section 54D(3), an authorized institution must allocate a risk-weight to the exposure in accordance with Table 4.

leadIn.b:
Risk-weights for Bank Exposures with Credit Quality
Grades Obtained by Mapping to ST ECAI Rating
Mapping Table for Type A ECAIs

td.p: Risk-weight for general bank exposures and short-term bank exposures

section.name: s59A
section.heading: Provisions supplementary to section 59

subsection.leadIn: Despite section 59(2), an authorized institution must allocate a risk-weight of 150% to a general bank exposure or a 3 months’ bank exposure to a bank—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: if—

subparagraph.content: section 54D(6) applies to the exposure; and
there is a reference exposure to the same bank; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if sections 54D(3) and 59(3) applied to the reference exposure, it would be allocated a risk-weight of 150% in accordance with those sections.

subsection.leadIn: The risk-weight allocated under section 59(2) to a bank exposure that is not a 6 months’ bank exposure and has an original maturity of 1 year or less (subject exposure) must not be lower than 100%—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: if—

subparagraph.content: section 54D(6) applies to the subject exposure; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if sections 54D(3) and 59(3) applied to the reference exposures, one or more of the reference exposures would be allocated a risk-weight of 50% or 100% in accordance with those sections.

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a bank exposure (subject exposure) to which section 54D(6) applies is a 3 months’ bank exposure; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: there are one or more reference exposures to the same bank but none of the reference exposures falls within subsection (1)(b) or (2)(b),

subsection.continued: the subject exposure must be allocated a risk-weight in accordance with subsection (4).

subsection.leadIn: If subsection (3) applies, the subject exposure must be allocated a risk-weight that is the higher of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the risk-weight that would be allocated to the reference exposures in accordance with sections 54D(3) and 59(3) if those sections applied to the reference exposures; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the risk-weight that would be allocated to the subject exposure in accordance with sections 54D(6) and 59(2) if those sections applied to the subject exposure as if there were no reference exposures.

subsection.content: For the purposes of subsection (4), if the 2 risk-weights referred to in subsection (4)(a) and (b) are the same, any one of those risk-weights may be allocated to the subject exposure.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: reference exposure (參照風險承擔), in relation to a bank exposure to which section 54D(6) applies, means another exposure to the same bank that has a short-term ECAI issue specific rating, regardless of who is holding that other exposure.

section.name: s59B
section.heading: Bank exposures—standardized credit risk assessment approach—assignment of credit assessment grade

subsection.content: This section applies to an unrated exposure to a bank other than an eligible covered bond exposure.
An authorized institution must assign a credit assessment grade to the exposure in accordance with subsections (3), (4) and (5).

subsection.leadIn: The institution must not assign a credit assessment grade of A to the exposure unless the institution assesses that the bank—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has adequate capacity to meet its financial commitments (including repayments of principal and interest) in a timely manner, for the projected life of the assets or exposures concerned and irrespective of the economic cycles and business conditions; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: meets or exceeds the published minimum regulatory requirements (including buffers) established by the relevant supervisor.

subsection.leadIn: The institution may assign a credit assessment grade of B to the exposure if the institution assesses that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the bank falls within either or both of subparagraphs (i) and (ii)—

subparagraph.leadIn: the bank—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: does not fall within subsection (3)(a); and

subparagraph.name: B

subparagraph.content: the bank does not fall within subsection (3)(b), including because of the absence of a buffer requirement in the published minimum regulatory requirements applicable to the bank; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the bank meets or exceeds the published minimum regulatory requirements (excluding buffers) established by the relevant supervisor.

subsection.leadIn: The institution must assign a credit assessment grade of C to the exposure if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the institution assesses that—

subparagraph.leadIn: the bank—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: does not fall within subsection (3)(a) or (4)(a)(i)(B); and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: has material default risks and limited margins of safety; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the institution assesses that—

subparagraph.content: the bank fails to meet the published minimum regulatory requirements (excluding buffers) established by the relevant supervisor; or
the minimum quantitative regulatory requirements imposed by the relevant supervisor are not publicly disclosed or otherwise made available by the bank to the institution; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the external auditor of the bank has issued an adverse audit opinion or has expressed substantial doubt about the bank’s ability to continue as a going concern in the bank’s financial statements or audited reports issued within the previous 12 months.

subsection.content: Despite subsections (2), (3), (4) and (5), an authorized institution must assign a credit assessment grade of C to an unrated exposure to a bank if the institution chooses not to conduct an assessment to determine whether the bank would be eligible for a credit assessment grade of A or B.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: home jurisdiction (原屬司法管轄區), in relation to a bank, means the jurisdiction in which the bank is incorporated;

published minimum regulatory requirements (已公布最低監管規定)—(a)in relation to an internationally active bank, means the minimum quantitative regulatory requirements imposed by the relevant supervisor on the bank that are—(i)consistent with the Basel Framework; and(ii)publicly disclosed or otherwise made known by the bank to its creditors or counterparties;(b)in relation to a bank that is not an internationally active bank, means the minimum quantitative regulatory requirements imposed by the relevant supervisor on the bank—(i)that include at least a minimum regulatory capital requirement; and(ii)that are publicly disclosed or otherwise made known by the bank to its creditors or counterparties; and(c)do not include—(i)liquidity standards; or(ii)bank-specific minimum regulatory requirements—(A)that may be imposed through supervisory actions taken by the relevant supervisor; and(B)that are not made public;

relevant supervisor (有關監管者), in relation to a bank, means—(a)the Monetary Authority if the bank is an authorized institution incorporated in Hong Kong; or(b)in any other case, the relevant banking supervisory authority in the bank’s home jurisdiction.

section.name: s59C
section.heading: Bank exposures—standardized credit risk assessment approach—allocation of risk-weight

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2), an authorized institution must allocate a risk-weight to an unrated exposure to a bank in accordance with Table 4A based on the credit assessment grade assigned by the institution to the unrated exposure under section 59B(2).

leadIn.b: Risk-weights for Unrated Exposures to Banks

subsection.leadIn: An authorized institution may allocate a risk-weight of 30% to an unrated exposure to a bank if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the institution assigns a credit assessment grade of A to the bank under section 59B(2); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the bank has—

subparagraph.content: a CET1 capital ratio, calculated in the manner specified by the relevant supervisor of the bank, that meets or exceeds 14%; and
a leverage ratio, calculated in the manner specified by the relevant supervisor of the bank, that meets or exceeds 5%.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (4), an unrated exposure to a bank must not be allocated under subsection (1) or (2) a risk-weight that is lower than the attributed risk-weight of the sovereign of the bank’s home jurisdiction if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the unrated exposure is not denominated in the local currency of the home jurisdiction; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the unrated exposure—

subparagraph.content: is booked in a branch of the bank in a jurisdiction other than its home jurisdiction (host jurisdiction); and
is not denominated in the local currency of the host jurisdiction.

subsection.content: Subsection (3) does not apply to an unrated exposure to a bank that is a trade-related contingency.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: attributed risk-weight (歸屬風險權重), in relation to a sovereign—(a)if the sovereign has an ECAI issuer rating or a long-term ECAI issue specific rating assigned to a debt obligation of the sovereign—means the risk-weight that would be attributable, in accordance with sections 54D and 55(1), to a senior and unsecured exposure (other than a domestic currency exposure) to the sovereign based on that rating; or(b)in any other case—means the risk-weight that would be attributable, in accordance with section 55(2), to an unrated exposure (other than a domestic currency exposure) to the sovereign;
home jurisdiction (原屬司法管轄區) has the meaning given by section 59B(7);
relevant supervisor (有關監管者) has the meaning given by section 59B(7).

section.name: s59D
section.heading: Eligible covered bond exposures

subsection.leadIn: Subject to section 54C, an authorized institution must allocate a risk-weight to an eligible covered bond exposure that has been assigned a credit quality grade under section 54D(2) in accordance with Table 4B.

leadIn.b: Risk-weights for Eligible Covered Bonds with Long-term ECAI Issue Specific Ratings

subsection.leadIn: Subject to section 54C, if no credit quality grade can be assigned to an eligible covered bond exposure under section 54D(2), an authorized institution must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: determine the attributed risk-weight of the issuer of the eligible covered bond; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: allocate a risk-weight to the eligible covered bond exposure in accordance with Table 4C based on the attributed risk-weight of the issuer determined under paragraph (a).

leadIn.b: Risk-weights for Eligible Covered Bonds without Long-term ECAI Issue Specific Ratings

td.p: Risk-weight for eligible covered bond exposures

subsection.content: For the purposes of subsection (2), if the issuer of an eligible covered bond is a financial institution other than a bank, an authorized institution may determine the attributed risk-weight of the issuer in a manner as if the issuer were a bank.

subsection.leadIn: The Monetary Authority must develop implementing technical standards to specify the conditions a covered bond must meet in order to be recognized as an eligible covered bond for the purposes of this section, including—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the types and qualities of claims included in the underlying assets of the covered bond;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the size of the underlying assets assigned to the covered bond relative to the size of the outstanding amount of the covered bond; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: information that must be made available to investors on a regular basis.

section.name: s60
section.heading: Exposures to qualifying non-bank financial institutions

subsection.content: This section applies to a qualifying non-bank financial institution exposure that is neither an eligible covered bond exposure nor an exposure that falls within section 64A.
If the exposure has been assigned a credit quality grade under section 54D(2), (3) or (6), sections 59 and 59A apply to the exposure as they apply to a bank exposure that is not an unrated exposure.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (4), if the exposure is an unrated exposure, sections 59B and 59C apply to the exposure as they apply to a bank exposure that is an unrated exposure, as if a reference in section 59B to published minimum regulatory requirements were a reference to the minimum quantitative regulatory requirements—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: that are—

subparagraph.content: publicly disclosed or otherwise made known by the qualifying non-bank financial institution to its creditors or counterparties; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: that do not include—

subparagraph.content: liquidity standards; or

subparagraph.leadIn: institution-specific minimum regulatory requirements—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: that may be imposed through supervisory actions taken by the regulatory authority; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: that are not made public.

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the exposure is an unrated exposure; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the obligor in respect of the exposure is a qualifying non-bank financial institution within the meaning of paragraph (a) or (b) of the definition of qualifying non-bank financial institution in section 2(1),

subsection.continued: an authorized institution must allocate to the unrated exposure a risk-weight of 75% if the exposure is a general bank exposure or a risk-weight of 50% if the exposure is a short-term bank exposure.

section.name: s61
section.heading: General corporate exposures

subsection.content: Subject to subsections (3) and (4) and section 54C, an authorized institution must allocate a risk-weight to a general corporate exposure that has been assigned a credit quality grade under section 54D(2), (3), (4), (6) or (7) in accordance with Table 5.

td.p: Risk-weight for credit quality grade obtained by mapping to LT ECAI rating mapping table for Type A ECAIs
Risk-weight for credit quality grade obtained by mapping to LT ECAI rating mapping table for Type B ECAIs

Risk-weight for
credit quality grade obtained by mapping to ST ECAI rating mapping table for Type A ECAIs

Risk-weight for
credit quality grade obtained by mapping to ST ECAI rating mapping table for Type B ECAIs

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsections (3) and (4), if a general corporate exposure is an unrated exposure—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to paragraph (b), an authorized institution must allocate a risk-weight of 100% to the general corporate exposure; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an authorized institution may allocate a risk-weight of 85% to the general corporate exposure if the corporate concerned is a small business.

subsection.leadIn: An authorized institution must allocate a risk-weight of 150% to a general corporate exposure—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: if—

subparagraph.content: the exposure is an exposure to which section 54D(6) or (7) applies or an unrated exposure; and
there is a reference exposure to the same corporate; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if subsection (1) and section 54D(3) or (4) applied to the reference exposure, it would be allocated a risk-weight of 150% in accordance with those provisions.

subsection.leadIn: The risk-weight allocated to a general corporate exposure with an original maturity of 1 year or less under subsection (1) or (2), as the case requires, must not be lower than 100%—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: if—

subparagraph.content: the exposure is an exposure to which section 54D(6) or (7) applies or an unrated exposure; and
there are one or more reference exposures to the same corporate but none of the reference exposures falls within subsection (3)(b); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if subsection (1) and section 54D(3) or (4) applied to the reference exposures, one or more of the reference exposures would be allocated a risk-weight of 50% or 100% in accordance with those provisions.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: reference exposure (參照風險承擔), in relation to a general corporate exposure that does not have an ECAI issue specific rating, means another general corporate exposure to the same corporate that has a short-term ECAI issue specific rating, regardless of who is holding that other general corporate exposure.

section.name: s62
section.heading: Specialized lending

subsection.content: Subject to section 54C, an authorized institution must allocate a risk-weight to a specialized lending that has been assigned a credit quality grade under section 54D(2) or (3) in accordance with Table 5.

subsection.leadIn: An authorized institution must allocate to a specialized lending that does not have an ECAI issue specific rating a risk-weight of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the lending arises from an object finance—100%;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the lending arises from a commodities finance—100%;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if the lending arises from a project finance (whether high quality or not)—130% during the preoperational phase;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: if the lending arises from a high quality project finance—80% during the operational phase; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: if the lending arises from a project finance, other than a high quality project finance—100% during the operational phase.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (2), a specialized lending arising from a high quality project finance is an exposure to a project finance entity where—

paragraph.name: a
b
c
d
paragraph.content: the revenues are availability-based or subject to a rate-of-return regulation or take-or-pay contract;

paragraph.name: e
f
paragraph.content: the contractual provisions governing the exposure provide for a high degree of protection for creditors in case of a default of the entity;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the main counterparty, or other counterparties that similarly comply with the eligibility criteria set out in paragraph (e) for the main counterparty, will protect the creditors from the losses resulting from a termination of the project;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: all assets and contracts necessary to operate the project have been pledged (or otherwise provided as security) to the creditors to the extent permitted by applicable law; and
creditors may assume control of the entity in case of a default of the entity.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (3)(d), the revenues are availability-based if—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: the availability payments are sized to cover operating and maintenance costs, debt service costs and equity returns as the project finance entity operates the project; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the availability payments are not subject to swings in demand, such as traffic levels, and are adjusted typically only for lack of performance or lack of availability of the asset to the public of the jurisdiction in which the asset is located.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: preoperational phase (營運前階段), in relation to a project finance, means the phase before the operational phase.

section.name: s64
section.heading: Retail exposures

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (7), an authorized institution must allocate—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: a risk-weight of 75% to a regulatory retail exposure to an obligor if—

subparagraph.content: the exposure arises from a credit facility other than a revolving credit facility or the obligor is not a transactor in respect of the exposure; and
the obligor is not a transactor in respect of any other exposure;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: to a regulatory retail exposure to an obligor—

subparagraph.content: a risk-weight of 45% if the obligor is a transactor in respect of the exposure; or

subparagraph.leadIn: a risk-weight of 75% if—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: the exposure arises from a credit facility other than a revolving credit facility or the obligor is not a transactor in respect of the exposure; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: the institution has another exposure to the obligor that falls within subparagraph (i); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a risk-weight of 100% to an exposure (other than a real estate exposure, an exposure that falls within section 64A or a defaulted exposure) to an individual, if the exposure is not a regulatory retail exposure (other retail exposure).

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1), an exposure of an authorized institution to a single obligor, or to a particular obligor in a group of obligors that is considered by the institution as a group of obligors for risk management purposes (including, but not limited to, those grouped under the Banking (Exposure Limits) Rules (Cap. 155 sub. leg. S)), is a regulatory retail exposure if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that single obligor, or that particular obligor in the group of obligors, is an individual or a small business;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the exposure is none of the following—

subparagraph.content: a real estate exposure;
a default risk exposure in respect of derivative contracts entered into with the obligor;
an exposure that falls within section 64A;
a defaulted exposure;
a holding of securities issued by the obligor, whether listed or not;
an exposure that falls within Subdivision 6 or section 65K or 65L;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: the exposure arises from a transaction, whether drawn down or not, that takes any of the following forms—

subparagraph.content: a revolving credit facility or a line of credit to an individual (such as a credit card or an overdraft);
a term loan or a lease to an individual (such as an auto loan or other instalment loan);

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the maximum aggregate exposure of the institution to that single obligor, or to that group of obligors, does not exceed $10 million; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: no aggregate exposure of the institution to that single obligor, or to that group of obligors, exceeds 0.2% of the institution’s overall regulatory retail portfolio.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (2)(d) and (e), aggregate exposure—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: includes all forms of exposures (other than real estate exposures secured by residential properties) to an individual or a small business (in-scope exposures); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be calculated by aggregating the exposure amounts of the in-scope exposures without taking into account any recognized credit risk mitigation.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (2)(e), an authorized institution must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: identify the full set of exposures to individuals and small businesses;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: from the full set of exposures identified under paragraph (a), identify the subset of exposures that meet all the criteria specified in subsection (2)(a), (b), (c) and (d); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: regard the subset of exposures identified under paragraph (b) as the institution’s overall regulatory retail portfolio.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (6) applies if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an authorized institution has any branch or subsidiary in a jurisdiction outside Hong Kong (relevant jurisdiction);

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: transfer of any information on the relevant exposures necessary for complying with subsection (6) outside the relevant jurisdiction is not prohibited by law.

subsection.leadIn: The institution must include in the aggregate exposure referred to in subsection (3) and the full set of exposures identified under subsection (4)(a)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for the purpose of calculating its capital adequacy ratio on a solo basis—the relevant exposures of its overseas branches; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the purpose of calculating its capital adequacy ratio on a solo-consolidated basis or consolidated basis—the relevant exposures of its overseas branches and overseas subsidiaries subject to the consolidation.

subsection.content: If a regulatory retail exposure or other retail exposure is an unhedged credit exposure, an authorized institution must apply a multiplier of 1.5 to the risk-weight applicable to the exposure determined under subsection (1), subject to a cap of 150%.

section.name: s64A
section.heading: Exposures arising from IPO financing

subsection.leadIn: This section applies to a credit facility granted by an authorized institution to a qualifying non-bank financial institution, a corporate or an individual (borrower) if— (L.N. 167 of 2023)

paragraph.name: a
b
c
paragraph.content: the money advanced by the institution under the facility is still legally owned and held by, and under the control of, the institution until the settlement of the payment for the securities successfully subscribed.

subsection.leadIn: The institution may allocate a risk-weight of 0% to its exposure arising from the facility during the period between the time the commitment to extend the facility is made by the institution and the time—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: payment for the securities successfully subscribed is made by the institution to the receiving bank of the issuer of the securities; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the IPO is cancelled before the payment referred to in paragraph (a) is made, the outstanding loan amount under the facility is fully repaid.

section.name: s65
section.heading: What are regulatory real estate exposures

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (3), a real estate exposure (other than an ADC exposure) of an authorized institution to an obligor is a regulatory real estate exposure if all of the following criteria are met in respect of the exposure—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: any claim on the mortgaged property is legally enforceable in all relevant jurisdictions;

paragraph.name: c
d
paragraph.content: the exposure is secured by a first legal charge on the mortgaged property or, if the mortgaged property falls within subsection (2)(c), the exposure will be secured by a first legal charge on the residential property after it is fully completed;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: the exposure is granted for one or more of the following purposes—

subparagraph.content: financing the acquisition of the mortgaged property;
refinancing the acquisition of the mortgaged property;
cashing out the equity in the mortgaged property;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.leadIn: the institution’s underwriting policies with respect to the granting of real estate exposures are adequate and prudent and include—

subparagraph.content: assessment of the ability of the obligor to repay; and

paragraph.name: g
h
paragraph.content: all the information (including information on the ability of the obligor to repay and on the valuation of the mortgaged property) required at loan origination and for monitoring purposes is properly documented.

subsection.leadIn: Immovable property falls within this subsection if the property is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a fully-completed immovable property;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: forest or agricultural land; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: a residential property under construction or land on which a residential property will be constructed where—

subparagraph.content: the real estate exposure secured by which is granted to an individual or a property-holding shell company owned by an individual who is the guarantor of the exposure; and

subparagraph.leadIn: either of the following conditions is met—

subparagraph.name: A
B
subparagraph.content: the institution is able to demonstrate, with the support of written and reasoned legal advice, that the sovereign of the jurisdiction (including Hong Kong) in which the property or land is located or any public sector entity of that jurisdiction has the legal power and ability to ensure that the property under construction or to be constructed will be finished.

subsection.leadIn: An authorized institution may classify a real estate exposure secured by a residential property as a regulatory real estate exposure despite the criteria set out in subsection (1) if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the exposure was originated before the commencement date* of Part 3 of the Banking (Capital) (Amendment) Rules 2023;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the exposure was eligible for a risk-weight of 35% under subsection (1) as in force immediately before that date; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: there has been no material change to the loan terms and conditions since that date.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of sections 65B, 65C and 65D—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to paragraphs (b), (c) and (d), a real estate exposure depends materially on the cash flows generated by the mortgaged property if both the servicing of the exposure and the prospects for recovery in the event of default depend materially on the cash flows generated by the mortgaged property, rather than on the income, revenue and net worth of the obligor generated from other sources;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: an authorized institution may treat a regulatory real estate exposure as an exposure that does not depend materially on the cash flows generated by the mortgaged property (non-IPRE exposure) if the mortgaged property is a residential property that is—

subparagraph.content: the primary residence of the obligor in respect of the exposure; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: an authorized institution may treat a regulatory real estate exposure that does not fall within paragraph (b) as a non-IPRE exposure if the mortgaged property is a residential property and both of the following conditions are met—

subparagraph.content: the total number of residential properties (including the mortgaged property but excluding any residential property that falls within paragraph (b)(i) or (ii)) pledged (or otherwise provided as security) to the institution by the individual and any property-holding shell company owned by the individual is 2 or fewer; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: for any real estate exposure that was originated before the commencement date of Part 3 of the Banking (Capital) (Amendment) Rules 2023, an authorized institution may, if information necessary for assessment is not sufficient or readily available, treat the exposure as a non-IPRE exposure.

section.name: s65A
section.heading: Loan-to-value ratio

subsection.leadIn: The loan-to-value ratio (LTV ratio) of a regulatory real estate exposure (subject exposure) secured by one or more immovable properties (subject security) must be calculated as a ratio of the amount specified in paragraph (a) to the amount specified in paragraph (b)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the sum of—

subparagraph.content: the principal amount of any outstanding drawn portion of the subject exposure (including accrued interest); and
the amount of any undrawn committed portion of the subject exposure;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the value at origination of the subject security, with the exceptions set out in subsections (6) and (7).

subsection.leadIn: If a pool of regulatory real estate exposures (collectively referred to as subject exposure) is secured by one or more immovable properties (subject security), the LTV ratio of the subject exposure must be calculated as a ratio of the amount specified in paragraph (a) to the amount specified in paragraph (b)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the sum of—

subparagraph.content: the amount of any undrawn committed portion of each of the regulatory real estate exposures in the pool;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the value at origination of the subject security, with the exceptions set out in subsections (6) and (7).

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a pool of real estate exposures is secured by one or more immovable properties (subject security); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the pool consists of both regulatory real estate exposures and real estate exposures that are neither regulatory real estate exposures nor ADC exposures,

subsection.continued: the LTV ratio applicable to the regulatory real estate exposures in the pool (subject exposures) must be calculated in accordance with subsection (2) where the reference to regulatory real estate exposures in subsection (2)(a) is taken to be a reference to all of the exposures in the pool referred to in paragraph (a).

subsection.leadIn: The numerator of the LTV ratio calculated under subsection (1), (2) or (3)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must not be reduced by any specific provisions; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: must not take into account the effect of any recognized credit risk mitigation (including mortgage insurance) except for cash on deposit with the authorized institution—

subparagraph.content: that is unconditionally and irrevocably pledged (or otherwise provided as security) by the obligor in respect of the subject exposure under a netting or offsetting agreement for the sole purpose of redemption of the subject exposure; and

subparagraph.leadIn: for which the security arrangement meets all of the following requirements—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: the institution has a well-founded legal basis for concluding that the netting or offsetting agreement with the obligor is enforceable in each relevant jurisdiction regardless of whether the obligor is insolvent or bankrupt;

subparagraph.name: B
C
D
subparagraph.content: the institution monitors and controls its exposures to the obligor on a net basis.

subsection.content: If a regulatory real estate exposure of an authorized institution secured by one or more immovable properties (subject security) was originated before the commencement date* of this section and the subject security was revalued at least once before that date, the institution may treat the value at the last revaluation conducted before that date as the value at origination of the subject security.

subsection.leadIn: In calculating the LTV ratio of a subject exposure under subsection (1), (2) or (3), an authorized institution must use a value lower than the value at origination of the subject security if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: downward adjustment of the value of the subject security is warranted by the prevailing local property market situations;

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: an extraordinary, idiosyncratic event occurs and results in a permanent reduction of the value of the subject security.

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an authorized institution incurs a new real estate exposure secured by a subject security that is also the security for at least one existing real estate exposure of the institution and an updated valuation of the security is obtained as part of the new loan application process in relation to the new real estate exposure, the institution may use the updated valuation in calculating the LTV ratio of the pool of regulatory real estate exposures secured by the subject security under subsection (2) or (3);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the value of a subject security has been adjusted downwards under subsection (6)(a), an authorized institution may make a subsequent upward adjustment to the value of the subject security and, except in cases where the resultant adjusted value is higher than the value at origination of the subject security, use the resultant adjusted value in the LTV ratio calculation under subsection (1), (2) or (3);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the value of a subject security has been adjusted downwards under subsection (6)(b), an authorized institution may, with the prior consent of the Monetary Authority, make a subsequent upward adjustment to the value of the subject security and use the resultant adjusted value in the LTV ratio calculation under subsection (1), (2) or (3); and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: modifications are made to an immovable property included in a subject security that unequivocally increase the value of the property and there is an updated valuation that confirms the increase in value, an authorized institution may take into account that increase in the LTV ratio calculation under subsection (1), (2) or (3).

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: value at origination (批出承擔時價值)—(a)in relation to a regulatory real estate exposure of an authorized institution secured by one or more immovable properties, means the valuation of the property or properties obtained by the institution at the time of origination of the exposure; and(b)in relation to a pool of real estate exposures of an authorized institution originated at the same time and secured by one or more immovable properties, means the valuation of the property or properties obtained by the institution at the time of origination of the pool.

section.name: s65B
section.heading: Risk-weights of regulatory residential real estate exposures

subsection.content: This section applies to a regulatory real estate exposure of an authorized institution that is secured by a residential property, including such a regulatory real estate exposure to a member of its staff (whether solely or jointly with another person).

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (4) and section 65E, if the exposure is an exposure that does not depend materially on cash flows generated by the residential property securing the exposure (non-IPRE exposure), the institution must allocate a risk-weight to the exposure in accordance with Table 6 based on the LTV ratio of the exposure calculated under section 65A.

leadIn.b: Risk-weights for Regulatory Residential Real Estate Exposures that are Non-IPRE Exposures

td.p: More than 50% but not more than 60%
More than 60% but not more than 80%
More than 80% but not more than 90%
More than 90% but not more than 100%

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (4) and section 65E, if the exposure is not a non-IPRE exposure, the institution must allocate a risk-weight to the exposure in accordance with Table 7 based on the LTV ratio of the exposure calculated under section 65A.

leadIn.b: Risk-weights for Regulatory Residential Real Estate Exposures that are not Non-IPRE Exposures

td.p: More than 50% but not more than 60%
More than 60% but not more than 80%
More than 80% but not more than 90%
More than 90% but not more than 100%

subsection.content: If the exposure is an unhedged credit exposure, the institution must apply a multiplier of 1.5 to the risk-weight applicable to the exposure determined under subsection (2) or (3), as the case requires, subject to a cap of 150%.

section.name: s65C
section.heading: Risk-weights of regulatory commercial real estate exposures

subsection.content: This section applies to a regulatory real estate exposure of an authorized institution to an obligor that is secured by a property other than residential property.

subsection.leadIn: If the exposure is an exposure that does not depend materially on cash flows generated by the property securing the exposure (non-IPRE exposure), the institution must allocate a risk-weight to the exposure in accordance with Table 8 based on the LTV ratio of the exposure calculated under section 65A.

leadIn.b: Risk-weights for Regulatory Commercial Real Estate Exposures that are Non-IPRE Exposures

td.p: Min (60%, attributed risk-weight of the obligor)

subsection.leadIn: If the exposure is not a non-IPRE exposure, the institution must allocate a risk-weight to the exposure in accordance with Table 9 based on the LTV ratio of the exposure calculated under section 65A.

leadIn.b: Risk-weights for Regulatory Commercial Real Estate Exposures that are not Non-IPRE Exposures

td.p: More than 60% but not more than 80%

section.name: s65D
section.heading: Risk-weights of other real estate exposures

subsection.content: This section applies to a real estate exposure of an authorized institution that is neither a regulatory real estate exposure nor an ADC exposure.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to section 65E, if the exposure does not depend materially on the cash flows generated by the property securing the exposure, the institution must allocate to the exposure—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a risk-weight of 75% if the obligor in respect of the exposure is an individual;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a risk-weight of 85% if the obligor in respect of the exposure is a small business; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in any other case, the attributed risk-weight of the obligor.

subsection.content: Despite subsection (2)(b), the institution may allocate a risk-weight of 100% to the exposure if the obligor in respect of the exposure is a corporate and the institution has not verified whether the corporate is a small business.
Subject to section 65E, if the exposure depends materially on the cash flows generated by the property securing the exposure, the institution must allocate a risk-weight of 150% to the exposure.

section.name: s65E
section.heading: Risk-weights of real estate exposures secured by residential property outside Hong Kong
section.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a real estate exposure (other than an ADC exposure) of an authorized institution is secured by a residential property outside Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the relevant supervisory authority of the jurisdiction in which the residential property is situated has implemented capital adequacy standards that were formulated in accordance with the Basel Framework,

section.continued: the institution may allocate a risk-weight to the exposure provided for under the capital adequacy standards (but excluding any approach that is based on internal models) applicable to banks incorporated in that jurisdiction.

section.name: s65F
section.heading: ADC exposures

subsection.content: Subject to subsections (2) and (3), an authorized institution must allocate a risk-weight of 150% to an ADC exposure.

subsection.leadIn: An ADC exposure in respect of residential property situated in Hong Kong may be allocated a risk-weight of 100% if both of the following criteria are met—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: the obligor in respect of the ADC exposure has substantial equity at risk, where the equity at risk is determined as an appropriate amount of obligor-contributed equity to the property’s appraised as-completed value.

subsection.leadIn: If—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an authorized institution has an ADC exposure in respect of one or more residential properties situated in a jurisdiction outside Hong Kong (subject ADC exposure); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the relevant banking supervisory authority of the jurisdiction—

subparagraph.content: has implemented the standardized approach for credit risk under the current Basel Framework; and

would, under the standardized approach for credit risk set out in the capital adequacy standards of the jurisdiction, permit banks incorporated in the jurisdiction to allocate a risk-weight that is lower than 150% to certain ADC exposures in respect of residential properties situated in the jurisdiction,

subsection.continued: the institution may allocate the same lower risk-weight to the subject ADC exposure if the conditions for the lower risk-weight specified in the capital adequacy standards of the jurisdiction are met in respect of the subject ADC exposure.

subdivision.name: SD6
subdivision.heading: Equity Exposures, Capital Instruments other than Equity Exposures, Non-capital LAC Liabilities, etc.

section.name: s65G
section.heading: Equity exposures

subsection.leadIn: Subject to sections 65H and 65I, an authorized institution must allocate—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a risk-weight of 400% to a speculative unlisted equity exposure; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a risk-weight of 250% to an equity exposure that is not a speculative unlisted equity exposure.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: speculative unlisted equity exposure (投機性非上市股權風險承擔) means an equity investment in an unlisted company that is—(a)invested for short-term resale purposes; or(b)considered venture capital or similar investment that is—(i)subject to price volatility; and(ii)acquired in anticipation of significant future capital gains.

section.name: s65H
section.heading: Significant capital investments in commercial entities
section.leadIn: If the net book value of an authorized institution’s significant capital investment in a commercial entity exceeds 15% of the institution’s capital base as at the immediately preceding calendar quarter end date as reported in its capital adequacy ratio return, the institution must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to section 43(1)(n), allocate a risk-weight of 1 250% to the amount of the net book value of the investment that exceeds that 15%; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: allocate a risk-weight determined in accordance with section 65G(1)(a) or (b), as the case requires, to the amount of the net book value of the investment that does not exceed that 15%.

section.name: s65I
section.heading: Holdings of capital instruments issued by, and non-capital LAC liabilities of, financial sector entities

subsection.leadIn: If an authorized institution has an insignificant LAC investment that is a direct holding, indirect holding or synthetic holding of a capital instrument issued by, or a non-capital LAC liability of, a financial sector entity, any amount of the insignificant LAC investment that is not deducted from the institution’s capital base under sections 43(1)(o), 47(1)(c) and 48(1)(c) must be allocated—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a risk-weight determined in accordance with section 65G(1)(a) or (b), as the case requires, if the insignificant LAC investment is an equity exposure; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a risk-weight of 150% if the insignificant LAC investment is not an equity exposure.

subsection.leadIn: If an authorized institution has a significant LAC investment that is a direct holding, indirect holding or synthetic holding of a capital instrument issued by, or a non-capital LAC liability of, a financial sector entity, any amount of the significant LAC investment that is not deducted from the institution’s capital base under sections 43(1)(p), 47(1)(d) and 48(1)(d) must be allocated—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a risk-weight of 250% if the significant LAC investment is in a CET1 capital instrument; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in any other case—

subparagraph.content: a risk-weight determined in accordance with section 65G(1)(a) or (b), as the case requires, if the significant LAC investment is an equity exposure; or
a risk-weight of 150% if the significant LAC investment is not an equity exposure.

subsection.content: If an authorized institution maintains any non-capital LAC debt resources and has holdings of non-capital LAC liabilities that fall within section 48A, the institution must allocate a risk-weight of 150% to any amount of the holdings that is not deducted from the institution’s capital base under section 48(1)(g)(i).

section.name: s65J
section.heading: Exposures to subordinated debts
section.content: An authorized institution must allocate a risk-weight of 150% to an exposure to a subordinated debt issued by a bank, qualifying non-bank financial institution or corporate.

subdivision.name: SD7
subdivision.heading: Exposures not falling within Subdivision 3, 4, 5 or 6

section.name: s65K
section.heading: Cash and gold

subsection.leadIn: An authorized institution must allocate a risk-weight of 0% to the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: notes and coins owned by the institution that are the lawful currency of a jurisdiction and are held by the institution or in transit;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the institution’s holding of certificates of indebtedness issued by the Government for the issue of legal tender notes;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: gold bullion held by the institution, or gold bullion held on an allocated basis for the institution by another person, that is backed by gold bullion liabilities.

subsection.content: Gold bullion held on an unallocated basis for an authorized institution by another person that is backed by gold bullion liabilities must be risk-weighted as a claim on that person.
Gold bullion held by an authorized institution, or gold bullion held for the institution by another person, that is not backed by gold bullion liabilities must be allocated a risk-weight of 100%.

section.name: s65L
section.heading: Items in the process of clearing or settlement

subsection.leadIn: An authorized institution must allocate a risk-weight of 0% to the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an unsettled clearing item of the institution that is being processed through any interbank clearing system in Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any receivable from a transaction of the institution in securities, foreign exchange or commodities that is not yet due for settlement.

subsection.leadIn: An authorized institution must allocate a risk-weight of 20% to a cheque, draft or other item drawn on another bank—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that is payable to the account of the institution immediately on presentation; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that is in the process of collection.

subsection.leadIn: In the case of transactions in securities, foreign exchange and commodities that are entered into by an authorized institution on a delivery-versus-payment basis, if any of those transactions is outstanding after the settlement date in respect of the transaction concerned, the institution must allocate to the positive current exposure incurred by the institution under the transaction a risk-weight of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: 0% if the transaction is outstanding up to and including the 4th business day after the settlement date;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: 100% if the transaction remains outstanding from 5 to 15 business days (both days inclusive) after the settlement date;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: 625% if the transaction remains outstanding from 16 to 30 business days (both days inclusive) after the settlement date;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: 937.5% if the transaction remains outstanding from 31 to 45 business days (both days inclusive) after the settlement date; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: 1 250% if the transaction remains outstanding for 46 or more business days after the settlement date.

subsection.leadIn: In the case of transactions in securities, foreign exchange and commodities that are entered into by an authorized institution on a basis other than a delivery-versus-payment basis, if any of those transactions is outstanding after the settlement date in respect of the transaction concerned, the institution must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: if the transaction remains outstanding up to and including the 4th business day after the settlement date, risk-weight the following items as exposures to the counterparty to the transaction—

subparagraph.content: the amount of payment made, or the current market value of the thing delivered, by the institution under the transaction; and
any positive current exposure incurred by the institution under the transaction;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if the transaction remains outstanding for 5 or more business days after the settlement date, allocate a risk-weight of 1 250% to—

subparagraph.content: the amount of payment made, or the current market value of the thing delivered, by the institution under the transaction; and
any positive current exposure incurred by the institution under the transaction.

subsection.content: Unless otherwise stated in Part 6A, subsections (1)(b), (3) and (4) do not apply to repo-style transactions.

section.name: s66
section.heading: Other exposures that are not defaulted exposures

subsection.content: If an exposure is not a defaulted exposure and none of the sections in Subdivisions 3, 4, 5 and 6 or section 65K or 65L applies to the exposure, an authorized institution must allocate a risk-weight of 100% to the exposure.

If, in respect of an exposure of an authorized institution, the institution has difficulty in allocating any accrued interest under the exposure to the obligors of the institution, the institution may, with the prior consent of the Monetary Authority, treat the accrued interest as an exposure to which subsection (1) applies.

section.name: s67
section.heading: Defaulted exposures

subsection.leadIn: Despite Subdivisions 3, 4, 5 and 7 and section 65J, an authorized institution must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: allocate a risk-weight of 100% to a defaulted exposure that is a residential real estate exposure (other than an ADC exposure) where repayments do not depend materially on the cash flows generated by the residential property securing the exposure; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other case, allocate a risk-weight of 150% to a defaulted exposure.

subsection.leadIn: An exposure of an authorized institution to an obligor is a defaulted exposure if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the exposure is past due for more than 90 days; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the obligor is a defaulted borrower.

subsection.leadIn: Despite subsection (2)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: a retail exposure (being a regulatory retail exposure or an exposure to an individual that is neither a real estate exposure nor a regulatory retail exposure) of an authorized institution is a defaulted exposure if—

subparagraph.content: the exposure is past due for more than 90 days;
the exposure is put on non-accrued status;
a distressed restructuring of the exposure is agreed by the institution; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if—

subparagraph.content: the institution or any member of the consolidation group of the institution has other outstanding retail exposures to the obligor in respect of a defaulted exposure; and
those other outstanding retail exposures do not fall within paragraph (a)(i), (ii), (iii) or (iv),

paragraph.continued: the institution may choose whether to treat those other outstanding retail exposures as defaulted exposures for the purposes of this Part.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (2)(b), an obligor is a defaulted borrower in relation to an authorized institution if any one or more of the following events have occurred in respect of the obligor—

paragraph.name: a
