schedule.name: sch1A
schedule.heading: Transactions and Contracts not Subject to CVA Risk Capital Charge

section.name: s1
section.heading: Excepted transactions and contracts
section.leadIn: The following transactions and contracts are specified for the purposes of section 322J(1) of these Rules—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: OTC derivative transactions and SFTs with a qualifying CCP where the authorized institution concerned is a clearing member of the CCP; (L.N. 44 of 2020)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: OTC derivative transactions and SFTs with a clearing member of a qualifying CCP for which the risk-weighted amount of the default risk exposure incurred by an authorized institution as a direct client of the clearing member is calculated in accordance with section 226ZA(3) or (4) of these Rules; (L.N. 44 of 2020)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: OTC derivative transactions and SFTs with a qualifying CCP for which the risk-weighted amount of the default risk exposure incurred by an authorized institution as a direct client of a clearing member of the CCP is calculated in accordance with section 226ZB(2) or (3) of these Rules; (L.N. 44 of 2020)

paragraph.name: ca
paragraph.content: OTC derivative transactions and SFTs with a higher level client within a multi-level client structure associated with a qualifying CCP for which the risk-weighted amount of the default risk exposure incurred by an authorized institution within the structure to the higher level client is calculated in accordance with section 226ZBA(5) of these Rules; (L.N. 44 of 2020)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: recognized credit derivative contracts (within the meaning of section 51(1), 105, 139(1) or 227(1) of these Rules, as the case requires) purchased by an authorized institution to provide credit protection to the institution’s banking book exposures where— (L.N. 175 of 2017)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.leadIn: the exposures are—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: credit risk exposures other than default risk exposures in respect of OTC derivative transactions and (if the Monetary Authority requires the institution to calculate a CVA risk capital charge in respect of its SFTs under section 322J(2) of these Rules) SFTs; or (L.N. 167 of 2023)

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: default risk exposures in respect of OTC derivative transactions and SFTs that fall within paragraph (a), (b), (c), (ca) or (e); and (L.N. 44 of 2020)

subparagraph.name: ii

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: OTC derivative transactions and SFTs (other than those falling within paragraph (a), (b), (c), (ca) or (d))— (L.N. 44 of 2020)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: that are in default as determined under the terms and conditions of the transactions; (L.N. 44 of 2020)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in respect of which the losses due to the default have been recognized by the authorized institution concerned for accounting and reporting purposes; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the exposures in respect of which have been transformed into simple claims that do not have the risk characteristics of derivative contracts or SFTs. (L.N. 51 of 2013)

schedule.name: sch1B
schedule.heading: Minimum Requirements to be Satisfied for Approval under Section 23D(2) of these Rules to Use Standardized CVA Approach

section.name: s1
section.heading: General requirements
section.leadIn: An authorized institution that makes an application under section 23D(1) of these Rules to use the standardized CVA approach must demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Monetary Authority that—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: the institution uses the exposure models used in the calculation of its CVA risk capital charge (exposure models) for its CVA risk management framework that includes the identification, measurement, management, approval and internal reporting of the institution’s CVA risk;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the institution has a CVA desk (or a similar dedicated function) that is responsible for the risk management and hedging of CVA;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: the institution has a risk control unit that—

subparagraph.content: is functionally independent of the institution’s business credit and trading units (including the CVA desk);
reports directly to the institution’s senior management; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: the institution—

subparagraph.leadIn: clearly documents the exposure models and the internal policies, controls and procedures relating to the operation of the exposure models, including—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: the calculation of the exposures generated by the models with sufficient details for a third party to understand the operation, limitations and key assumptions, and to re-create the analysis;

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: the model validation process, including frequency and methodologies of validation and analyses used; and

subparagraph.name: C
subparagraph.content: criteria and process to analyse the performance of the exposure models including the model inputs and process to remedy any unacceptable performance; and
has a system for monitoring and ensuring compliance with those internal policies, controls and procedures;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: an independent review of the soundness and adequacy of the institution’s CVA risk management process and the institution’s compliance with internal policies, controls and procedures, including the requirements specified in this Schedule, is conducted regularly by the institution’s internal auditors; and

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the review or audit referred to in paragraph (f) includes the activities of the CVA desk and the independent risk control unit.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Specific requirements relating to principles in determining CVA for each counterparty
section.leadIn: For the purpose of determining the CVA for each counterparty and without limiting section 1 of this Schedule, an authorized institution must adhere to, and demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Monetary Authority that it adheres to, the following principles—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the institution calculates the CVA for each counterparty with at least one covered transaction as specified in section 322J of these Rules as the expectation of future losses resulting from the default of the counterparty under the assumption that the institution itself is free from default risk;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the institution calculates the CVA based on sets of inputs that include at a minimum—

subparagraph.leadIn: the term structure of market implied probability of default, which is determined based on the credit spread of market instruments of the counterparty but, if no market instrument of the counterparty is available—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: a proxy credit spread is determined based on credit spreads of market instruments of the liquid peers of the counterparty via an algorithm that discriminates on variables that include at a minimum the credit quality, industry and region of the counterparty;

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: a proxy credit spread may be determined based on a single liquid reference name with proper justification; or

subparagraph.name: C
subparagraph.content: if no credit spreads of any liquid peers of the counterparty are available because of the specific type of the counterparty, a fundamental analysis of credit risk may be conducted to proxy the credit spread of the counterparty on condition that the resulting proxy credit spread relates to credit markets;

market-consensus expected loss given default values that are consistent with the ones used to calculate the probability of default in subparagraph (i) and take into account the seniority of the exposure; and

simulated paths of discounted future exposures that are calculated by pricing all exposures with the counterparty along simulated paths of relevant market risk factors and discounting the prices back to the reporting date using risk-free rates along the path;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: in relation to the calculation of the simulated paths of discounted future exposures set out in paragraph (b)(iii), the exposure models—

subparagraph.content: take into account any significant level of dependence between an exposure and the credit quality of the counterparty;

are consistent with the exposure models used in the calculation of front office or accounting CVA (including the netting recognition), with adjustments if needed, to fulfil other requirements specified in this Schedule;
account for the possible non-normality of the distribution of exposures in the distribution of risk factors being modelled;
capture transaction-specific information in order to aggregate exposures at netting set level; and
reflect transaction terms and specifications in a timely, complete and conservative manner;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the exposure models have a proven track record of acceptable accuracy in measuring the CVA and CVA sensitivity to the market risk factors;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the option pricing models embedded in the exposure models account for the non-linearity of option value with respect to market risk factors;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the exposure models use current and historical data acquired in a timely and complete manner, and independently of the business lines and are compliant with the relevant financial reporting standards; and

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the use of any proxy market data provides a conservative representation of the underlying risk factor under adverse market conditions.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Additional requirements relating to exposure models
section.leadIn: Without limiting section 1 or 2 of this Schedule, an authorized institution must demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Monetary Authority that, if the exposure models used by the institution capture the effects of margin agreements when estimating the simulated paths of discounted future exposure—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the institution has a collateral management unit as required by section 1(e) of Schedule 2A;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: all documentation used in collateralized transactions are binding on all parties and legally enforceable in all relevant jurisdictions; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: the exposure models—

subparagraph.content: include transaction-specific information in order to capture the effects of margining along each exposure path; and

account for the nature of margin agreements (including whether the agreement concerned is unilateral or bilateral), the frequency of margin calls, the type of collateral, the margin thresholds, the independent amounts, the initial margins, the minimum transfer amounts and the margin period of risk.

schedule.name: sch2
schedule.heading: Minimum Requirements to be Satisfied for Approval under Section 8 of these Rules to Use IRB Approach

section.name: s1
section.heading: General requirements
section.leadIn: An authorized institution which makes an application under section 8 of these Rules to use the IRB approach shall demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Monetary Authority that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the board of directors (or a committee designated by the board) and the senior management of the institution—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: approve all the key elements of, and any material changes to, the institution’s rating system;

subparagraph.name: ii
iii
subparagraph.content: exercise oversight of the institution’s rating system sufficient to ensure that the rating system complies with paragraph (b); and

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.leadIn: ensure that there is a reporting system within the institution to provide information (including, but not limited to, information relating to any material changes to, or deviations from, established policies and procedures or any material findings identified in a review or audit referred to in paragraph (j)) to them regularly and in sufficient detail as will enable them to—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: exercise the oversight referred to in subparagraph (iii); and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: make informed decisions relating to credit approval, risk management and corporate governance and (where paragraph (b)(vi)(A) is applicable) internal capital adequacy assessment based on the information generated by the institution’s rating system;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the institution’s rating system—

subparagraph.name: i
ii
iii
subparagraph.content: is operated in a prudent and consistently effective manner;

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: is operated in compliance with Part 6 of these Rules or in a manner which although not fully in compliance with that Part, will not result in any material non-compliance with other requirements specified in this section;

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: plays an essential role in the institution’s ongoing credit approval, risk management and corporate governance functions;

subparagraph.name: vi
subparagraph.leadIn: either—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: plays an essential role in the institution’s ongoing internal capital adequacy assessment; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: will eventually play, within a period and in a manner agreed to by the Monetary Authority, an essential role in the institution’s ongoing internal capital adequacy assessment once the systems and procedures being developed by the institution as at the date of the institution’s application to use the IRB approach under section 8 of these Rules for conducting the assessment are implemented in accordance with a plan agreed to by the Monetary Authority; and (L.N. 167 of 2023)

subparagraph.name: viii
subparagraph.leadIn: enables the institution to comply with the Banking (Disclosure) Rules (Cap. 155 sub. leg. M) in respect of any disclosures by the institution in respect of— (L.N. 156 of 2012)

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: the institution’s credit risk; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: the manner in which the institution manages its credit risk;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: the institution has a credit risk control unit—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: which is functionally independent of the institution’s staff and management responsible for credit initiation;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: which reports directly to the institution’s senior management; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.leadIn: which is responsible for—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: the design or selection, testing and implementation of the institution’s rating system;

subparagraph.name: B
C
subparagraph.content: the monitoring and review of any override relating to the inputs to, or the outputs of, the institution’s rating system;

subparagraph.name: D
subparagraph.content: the production and analysis of the management reports generated by the institution’s rating system; and

subparagraph.name: E
subparagraph.content: the ongoing review of, and changes to, the institution’s rating system;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the institution has a sufficient number of staff who are qualified and trained to use the institution’s rating system in the institution’s business, risk control, audit and back office functions as will enable these functions to work effectively in identifying, measuring and controlling the institution’s credit risk;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the institution clearly documents all the key elements of, and the history of major changes in, the institution’s rating system and the contents of the documentation are consistent with, and evidence the institution’s compliance with, the requirements specified in this section;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the institution has an effective system to collect, store, process, retrieve and utilize data on obligor and facility characteristics and default and loss information in respect of the institution’s exposures in a reliable and consistent manner, and the data stored are in sufficient detail as will enable the institution to comply with the requirements specified in this section;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: where the institution uses models which are based on statistical techniques or expert judgment, or both, to assign exposures to obligor grades and facility grades, or pools, and to estimate the credit risk components in respect of those grades or pools, the use of those models will not result in any distortion in the calculation of the institution’s regulatory capital for credit risk;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.leadIn: the institution has a comprehensive stress-testing programme conducted regularly for the assessment of the adequacy of—

subparagraph.name: i
ii

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.leadIn: the institution has a reliable system for validating regularly the accuracy and consistency of the institution’s rating system (including models used as referred to in paragraph (g)), by persons who are qualified and trained to do so and who are independent of the development of the institution’s rating system, through—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: vetting data inputs to the institution’s rating system;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: reviewing the outputs of the institution’s rating system;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: evaluating the logic and conceptual soundness of the institution’s rating system;

subparagraph.name: iv
v
subparagraph.content: reviewing any proposed development of, or any proposed significant change to, the institution’s rating system to assess whether the rating system will function effectively as intended if the proposed development is implemented or the proposed change made, as the case may be; and (L.N. 137 of 2011)

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: an independent review or audit of the institution’s compliance with the requirements specified in this section is conducted regularly by the institution’s internal auditors or by independent external parties which are qualified to do so.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Specific requirements
section.leadIn: Without prejudice to the generality of section 1, an authorized institution shall demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Monetary Authority that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the suitability and capability of the institution’s rating system for the purposes of section 1(b)(i) and (ii) are supported by parallel calculations carried out prior to the use of the IRB approach for the calculation of the institution’s regulatory capital for credit risk for such period as the Monetary Authority considers reasonable in all the circumstances of the case; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the institution has been using a rating system, and estimates of credit risk components generated by that rating system, which are broadly consistent with the requirements of Part 6 of these Rules for the estimation of credit risk components and the calculation of credit risk under the IRB approach, in the institution’s credit approval, risk management and corporate governance functions and (where section 1(b)(vi)(A) is applicable) internal capital adequacy assessment prior to the use of the IRB approach for the calculation of the institution’s regulatory capital for credit risk for such period as the Monetary Authority considers reasonable in all the circumstances of the case.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Meaning of parallel calculations
section.leadIn: In section 2(a), parallel calculations (對比計算), in relation to an authorized institution, means calculations—

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: of which—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: one set consists of those calculations derived from the approach the institution actually uses during the period covered by the parallel calculations to calculate its credit risk; and

subparagraph.name: ii

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: which contain such information, and use such data and methodology, as agreed between the Monetary Authority and the institution.

schedule.name: sch2A
schedule.heading: Minimum Requirements to be Satisfied for Approval under Section 10B(2)(a) of these Rules to Use IMM(CCR) Approach

section.name: s1
section.heading: General requirements
section.leadIn: An authorized institution that makes an application under section 10B(1) of these Rules to use the IMM(CCR) approach must demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Monetary Authority that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the board of directors (or a committee designated by the board) and the senior management of the institution—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: approve all the key elements of, and any material changes to, the institution’s counterparty credit risk management system (being the methods, models, processes, controls, and data collection and information technology systems used by the institution that enable the identification, measurement, management and control of counterparty credit risk by the institution);

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: possess an understanding of the design and operation of, and the management reports generated by, the institution’s counterparty credit risk management system adequate for them to perform their functions specified in this paragraph;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: exercise oversight of the institution’s counterparty credit risk management system sufficient to ensure that the system complies with paragraph (b); and

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.leadIn: ensure that there is a reporting system within the institution to provide information (including information relating to any material changes to, or deviations from, established policies and procedures or any material findings identified in a review or audit referred to in paragraph (k)) to them regularly and in sufficient detail as will enable them to—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: exercise the oversight referred to in subparagraph (iii); and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: make informed decisions relating to the institution’s counterparty credit risk exposures;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the institution’s counterparty credit risk management system—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: is suitable for the purposes of identifying, measuring, managing, controlling and reporting the institution’s counterparty credit risk taking into account the characteristics and extent of the institution’s counterparty credit risk exposures;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: identifies, measures, monitors and controls counterparty credit risk over the life of transactions;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: measures and manages both current exposures (gross and net of collateral held, where appropriate) and future exposures; and

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: is operated in a prudent and consistently effective manner that is also consistent with sound practices for counterparty credit risk management;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: the institution—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.leadIn: clearly documents the counterparty credit risk management system and the internal policies, controls and procedures relating to the operation of the system, including—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: the internal models to which the application relates (relevant models);

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: the calculation of the risk measures generated by the relevant models with sufficient details for a third party to re-create the risk measures; and

subparagraph.name: C
subparagraph.content: the model validation process, including frequency and methodologies of validation and analyses used; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: has a system for monitoring and ensuring compliance with those internal policies, controls and procedures;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: the institution has a risk control unit—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: that is functionally independent of the institution’s staff and management responsible for originating counterparty credit risk exposures;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: that reports directly to the institution’s senior management;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.leadIn: that is responsible for—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: the design or selection of the institution’s counterparty credit risk management system;

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: the testing, validation and implementation of the institution’s counterparty credit risk management system;

subparagraph.name: C
subparagraph.content: the oversight of the effectiveness of the institution’s counterparty credit risk management system for the purposes of paragraph (b), including the control of data integrity;

subparagraph.name: D
subparagraph.content: the production and analysis of daily management reports on the output of the relevant models, including an evaluation of the relationship between measures of counterparty credit risk exposure and credit and trading limits;

subparagraph.name: E
subparagraph.content: the ongoing review of, and changes to, the institution’s counterparty credit risk management system; and

subparagraph.name: F
subparagraph.content: the conduct of a regular back-testing programme to verify the accuracy and reliability of the relevant models;

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: the work of which is an integral part of the day-to-day credit risk management process of the institution, including the planning, monitoring and controlling of the institution’s credit and overall risk profile; and

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: the daily management reports of which are reviewed by a level of management with sufficient seniority and authority to enforce both reductions of positions taken by individual traders and reductions in the institution’s overall risk exposure;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: the institution has a collateral management unit—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: that is adequately staffed and with sufficient resources to process margin calls and disputes in a timely and accurate manner at all times (including during periods of severe market crisis), and to enable the institution to limit its number of large disputes caused by trade volumes; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.leadIn: that is responsible for—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: calculating and making margin calls, managing margin call disputes and reporting levels of independent amounts, initial margins (within the meaning of section 226A of these Rules) and variation margins (within the meaning of section 226A of these Rules) accurately on a daily basis; (L.N. 44 of 2020)

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: controlling the integrity of the data used to make margin calls and ensuring that such data are consistent and reconciled regularly with all relevant data sources within the institution;

subparagraph.name: C
subparagraph.content: tracking the extent of reuse of collateral posted to the institution (both cash and non-cash) and the rights ceded by the institution in respect of the collateral that it posts;

subparagraph.name: D
subparagraph.content: tracking concentration in individual types of collateral accepted by the institution; and

subparagraph.name: E
subparagraph.content: producing and maintaining appropriate collateral management information (including information on the type of collateral (both cash and non-cash) received and posted, categories of collateral reused and the terms of the reuse, the size, aging and cause of margin call disputes, and the trends in the areas to which such information relates) and reporting the information to the institution’s senior management on a regular basis;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the institution has a sufficient number of staff who are qualified and trained to use the relevant models in the institution’s business, risk control, audit and back office functions as will enable those functions to work prudently and effectively in identifying, measuring, managing, controlling and reporting the institution’s counterparty credit risk;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.leadIn: the use of the relevant models is part of the institution’s counterparty credit risk management system and plays an essential role in the institution’s daily risk management, capital planning and corporate governance functions, with—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.leadIn: the results generated by the relevant models being used in—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: planning, measuring, monitoring and controlling the institution’s counterparty credit risk exposures;

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: determining the institution’s trading and credit risk exposure limits and measuring the usage of those limits;

subparagraph.name: C
subparagraph.content: credit approval; and

subparagraph.name: D
subparagraph.content: internal capital allocation; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the relationship between the relevant models and the limits referred to in subparagraph (i)(B) being maintained consistently over time and understood by the institution’s senior management, credit function and staff engaged in trading activity;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.leadIn: the institution—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: uses stress-testing and scenario analysis to identify risk factors that give rise to general wrong-way risk (being the risk that arises when the probability of default of counterparties is positively correlated with general market risk factors) and address the possibility of severe shocks;

subparagraph.name: ii
iii
subparagraph.content: has policies and procedures for identifying, monitoring and controlling transactions with specific wrong-way risk at the inception and throughout the life of the transactions; and

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: provides regular reports on wrong-way risks to its senior management and board of directors (or a committee designated by the board);

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: the cash management policy of the institution takes account of the liquidity risks arising from potential incoming margin calls (including calls for posting of collateral due to adverse market shocks or potential downgrade of the institution’s external credit rating and calls for return of collateral);

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: the institution ensures that the nature and horizon of collateral reuse are consistent with its liquidity needs and do not jeopardize its ability to post or return collateral in a timely manner;

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: an independent review or audit of the soundness and adequacy of the institution’s counterparty credit risk management system and the institution’s compliance with internal policies, controls and procedures, including the requirements specified in this Schedule, in respect of the system is conducted regularly by the institution’s internal auditors or by independent external parties that are qualified to do so; and

paragraph.name: l
paragraph.leadIn: the institution, before being granted an IMM(CCR) approval—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: has been using internal models that are broadly consistent with the requirements set out in this Schedule, for a period (not less than one year in any case) that is considered by the Monetary Authority as reasonable in all the circumstances of the case, to estimate the distribution of exposures (within the meaning given in section 226H(2) of these Rules) using current market data; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: has been conducting back-testing, being back-testing that is broadly consistent with the requirements set out in this Schedule relating to back-testing, using historical data on movements in market risk factors.

section.name: s2
section.heading: Specific requirements relating to relevant models
section.leadIn: Without limiting section 1 of this Schedule, an authorized institution must demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Monetary Authority that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the relevant models specify the forecast of the probability distribution of changes in the market value of a netting set attributable to changes in relevant market factors and calculate the institution’s counterparty credit risk exposure for the netting set at each future date given the changes in the market factors;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the relevant models capture and accurately reflect, on a continuing basis, all material factors affecting counterparty credit risk inherent in the institution’s transactions;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the relevant models capture transaction specific information in order to aggregate exposures at netting set level;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the institution calculates counterparty credit risk on the basis of a distribution of exposures that accounts for the possible non-normality of the distribution of exposures;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the relevant models have a proven track record of acceptable accuracy in measuring counterparty credit risk;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the relevant models used for pricing options account for the non-linearity of option value with respect to market risk factors; and

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the relevant models are capable of estimating EE on a daily basis (unless the institution is able to otherwise demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Monetary Authority that a less frequent calculation is warranted) and the EE is estimated along a time profile of forecasting horizons that adequately reflects the time structure of future cash flows and maturity of transactions.

section.name: s3
section.heading: Specific requirements relating to integrity of modelling process
section.leadIn: Without limiting sections 1 and 2 of this Schedule, an authorized institution must demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Monetary Authority that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: transaction terms and specifications are reflected in the relevant models in a timely, complete, and conservative manner, and maintained in a secure database that is subject to formal and periodic audit;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the terms and specifications of any valid bilateral netting agreements or valid cross-product netting agreements are input into the database by an independent unit;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the transmission of data on transaction terms and specifications to the relevant models is subject to internal audit and the institution has formal processes for reconciliation between the relevant models and the source data systems to verify on an ongoing basis that transaction terms and specifications are reflected in EE correctly or at least conservatively;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: the institution has internal procedures to verify that—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: before including a transaction in a netting set, the transaction is covered by a valid bilateral netting agreement or a valid cross-product netting agreement, as the case may be, and the legal enforceability of the agreement has been verified by legal staff; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: before recognizing the effect of collateral in the calculation of counterparty credit risk, the collateral meets the legal certainty standards set out in section 77 of these Rules; (L.N. 167 of 2023)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: the institution, when calibrating its relevant models using historical market data—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: uses current market data to compute current exposures;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.leadIn: estimates the parameters of the models using either—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: at least 3 years of historical market data; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: market implied data; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: updates the data quarterly, or more frequently if market conditions warrant it;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.leadIn: for the purposes of performing the calculations referred to in section 226D(1)(b) of these Rules, the institution calibrates its relevant models and estimates the parameters of the models using either—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: 3 years of data that include a period of stress to the credit default spreads of the institution’s counterparties; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: market implied data from a suitable period of stress; and

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.leadIn: the institution adopts the following measures to ensure the soundness and adequacy of the stress calibration referred to in paragraph (f)—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.leadIn: the institution demonstrates, at least quarterly, that—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: the period of stress referred to in paragraph (f) coincides with a period of increased credit default swap spreads or other credit spreads of a representative selection of the institution’s counterparties with traded credit spreads; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: where adequate credit spread data for a counterparty is not available for the purposes of sub-subparagraph (A), the institution maps the counterparty to specific credit spread data based on the counterparty’s geographical location, internal rating and business type;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the relevant models use data (either historical or implied) that include data from a period of credit stress and use such data in a manner that is consistent with the method used for the calibration of the relevant models to current market data;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.leadIn: for the purposes of evaluating the effectiveness of its stress calibration, the institution creates several benchmark portfolios that are vulnerable to the same main risk factors to which the institution is exposed and compares the exposures to the benchmark portfolios calculated using—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: current positions at current market prices, and model parameters calibrated in the manner set out in paragraph (f)(i); and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: current positions at market prices at the end of the 3 years referred to in paragraph (f)(i), and model parameters calibrated in the manner set out in that paragraph.

section.name: s4
section.heading: Specific requirements relating to stress-testing
section.leadIn: Without limiting sections 1, 2 and 3 of this Schedule, an authorized institution must demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Monetary Authority that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the institution has a comprehensive stress-testing programme for counterparty credit risk that is conducted regularly and includes the following elements—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the programme comprehensively captures transactions and aggregates exposures across all forms of trading and across different product categories at the counterparty-specific level, and the time frame selected for the capturing and aggregation is commensurate with the frequency with which stress tests are conducted;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: there is at least monthly stress-testing of principal market risk factors, including interest rates, exchange rates, equities prices, credit spreads and commodity prices, for all counterparties of the institution to assess and address concentration in specific directional risks;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.leadIn: there is at least quarterly multifactor stress-testing to assess material non-directional risks including yield curve exposures and basis risks, and the stress-testing addresses, at a minimum, the following scenarios—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: severe economic or market events;

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: significant decrease in broad market liquidity;

subparagraph.name: C
subparagraph.content: the liquidation of a large financial intermediary;

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: there is at least quarterly stress-testing of joint movement of counterparty credit risk exposures and related counterparty creditworthiness;

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: the stress tests (including those referred to in subparagraphs (i), (ii), (iii) and (iv)) are conducted at the counterparty-specific level and the counterparty-group level (grouped by industry, region or other relevant criteria), and in aggregate at the institution-wide level;

subparagraph.name: vi
subparagraph.content: the severity of shocks is consistent with the purpose of the stress test;

subparagraph.name: vii
subparagraph.content: the programme includes provision, where appropriate, for reverse stress tests to identify extreme, but plausible, scenarios that could result in significant adverse outcomes; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the stress-testing results—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: are reported regularly to the institution’s senior management and periodically to the institution’s board of directors (or a committee designated by the board) and cover the largest counterparty-level impacts across the institution’s portfolio, material segmental concentrations (within the same industry or region) and portfolio and counterparty specific trends; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.leadIn: are used in—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: managing the institution’s counterparty credit risk, including the setting of policies, risk appetite and exposure limits and the identification and mitigation of excessive or concentrated risks relative to the institution’s risk appetite; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: performing the assessment of the adequacy of the institution’s regulatory capital and internal capital for counterparty credit risk and the institution’s ability to withstand any future events, or changes in economic conditions, that could have adverse effects on the institution’s counterparty credit risk exposures.

section.name: s5
section.heading: Specific requirements relating to model validation
section.leadIn: Without limiting sections 1, 2, 3 and 4 of this Schedule, an authorized institution must demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Monetary Authority that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the institution has a reliable validation system for validating the accuracy, comprehensiveness and consistency of the relevant models (including the risk measures and risk factor predictions generated by or used in the models) by parties—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: who are qualified and trained to do so and who are independent of the staff and management responsible for originating counterparty credit risk and the development of the relevant models; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: whose aim is to ascertain whether the relevant models are conceptually sound, able to capture all material factors affecting counterparty credit risk, and continue to perform as intended; (L.N. 167 of 2023)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the validation referred to in paragraph (a) must meet the following requirements—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.leadIn: the validation is conducted—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: when a relevant model is initially developed and thereafter regularly at a frequency that is adequate to reflect the recent performance of the model; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: when any significant changes are made to a relevant model or when there have been significant structural changes in the market or changes to the composition of the institution’s portfolio of exposures that might lead to the relevant model concerned no longer being adequate to capture all material factors affecting counterparty credit risk; (L.N. 167 of 2023)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the validation assesses the accuracy, comprehensiveness and consistency of the relevant models in respect of the results generated by the models at both the institution-wide level and the netting set level;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.leadIn: the validation procedures—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: are clearly documented in sufficient detail as will enable a third party to evaluate the appropriateness of the procedures and re-create the analysis performed by the institution;

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: define assessment criteria and describe the process by which unacceptable performance will be determined and remedied;

subparagraph.name: C
subparagraph.content: ensure that the relevant models cover all factors and products that have a material contribution to counterparty credit risk exposure; (L.N. 167 of 2023)

subparagraph.name: D
subparagraph.content: ensure that all counterparties for which the relevant models are used are covered by the validation;

subparagraph.name: E
subparagraph.content: ensure that both the assumptions and approximations underlying the relevant models are prudent and appropriate for the measurement of the institution’s counterparty credit risk exposures; and (L.N. 167 of 2023)

subparagraph.name: F

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the validation of the relevant models and the risk measures that produce forecasts of distributions assesses more than a single statistic of the distributions;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: as part of the initial and on-going validation process, the institution—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.leadIn: conducts appropriate back-testing to—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: assess the performance of the relevant models and the risk measures and market risk factor predictions that are used to estimate EE; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: test the key assumptions of the relevant models and the risk measures;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.leadIn: includes in back-testing—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: a number of distinct prediction time horizons set out to at least one year, over a range of various start dates and covering a wide range of market conditions; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: for collateralized transactions, prediction time horizons that reflect typical margin periods of risk applied in such transactions and long time horizons that are at least one year;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: tests the pricing models used to calculate counterparty credit risk exposure for a given scenario of future shocks to market risk factors and against appropriate independent benchmarks; (L.N. 167 of 2023)

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: verifies that transactions are assigned to an appropriate netting set within the relevant models;

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: conducts static, historical back-testing on representative counterparty portfolios, with the representative counterparty portfolios chosen based on their sensitivity to the material risk factors and correlations to which the institution is exposed;

subparagraph.name: vi
subparagraph.content: validates the relevant models and risk measures out to time horizons that are commensurate with the maturity of transactions covered by the institution’s IMM(CCR) approval; and

subparagraph.name: vii
subparagraph.content: assesses the frequency with which the parameters of the relevant models are updated; and

subparagraph.name: e
subparagraph.content: the validation results, including those of back-testing, are reviewed periodically by a level of management with sufficient authority to decide the actions that will be taken to address any weaknesses identified in the relevant models.

section.name: s6
section.heading: Additional requirements relating to relevant models that capture effects of margin agreements
section.leadIn: Without limiting sections 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5 of this Schedule, an authorized institution must demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Monetary Authority that, if the relevant models used by the institution capture the effects of margin agreements when estimating EE, the models—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: meet the requirements of sections 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5 of this Schedule in respect of the prediction of future collateral values;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: include transaction-specific information in order to capture the effects of margining;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: take into account both the current amount of collateral and collateral that would be passed between counterparties in the future;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: account for the nature of margin agreements (whether the agreement concerned is unilateral or bilateral), the frequency of margin calls, the margin period of risk, the margin thresholds, and the minimum transfer amount; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: either estimate the mark-to-market change in the value of collateral posted, or apply the rules for recognized collateral set out in Part 4, 5 or 6 of these Rules, as the case requires.

schedule.name: sch3
schedule.heading: Minimum Requirements to be Satisfied for Approval under Section 18 of these Rules to Use IMA

section.name: s1
section.heading: General requirements

subsection.leadIn: An authorized institution that applies under section 18 of these Rules to use the IMA must demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Monetary Authority that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the institution’s market risk management system is conceptually sound and implemented with integrity;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the institution has a sufficient number of staff who are qualified and trained to use the institution’s internal models to which the application relates (relevant models) in the institution’s business, risk control, audit and back office functions;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the relevant models have a proven track record of reasonable accuracy in measuring market risk and demonstrate that accuracy during a period of initial monitoring and live testing of the relevant models at the request of the Monetary Authority;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: the institution clearly documents the relevant models with—

subparagraph.content: the core model documentation, which covers all key components of the relevant models; and
the non-core model documentation, which covers a comprehensive range of detailed aspects of the relevant models;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: the institution has an appropriate organizational infrastructure (including the definition and structure of trading desks) and its firm-wide internal models meet the qualitative evaluation criteria specified by the Monetary Authority;

paragraph.name: f
g
paragraph.content: the relevant models capture and accurately reflect, on a continuing basis, all material risk factors affecting market risk inherent in the institution’s market risk exposures and determine whether each risk factor is modellable through identifying a sufficient number of real price observations in the risk factor eligibility test;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.leadIn: in respect of the relevant models for modellable risk factors—

subparagraph.content: ESF,C, ESR,C and ESR,S, as referred to in Formula 28C of these Rules, are calculated on a daily basis for each approved trading desk and across all approved trading desks;

subject to subsection (3), ESF,C,i, ESR,C,i and ESR,S,i, as referred to in Formula 28D of these Rules, are calculated at least on a weekly basis for each approved trading desk and across all approved trading desks on the basis that the weekly calculation does not lead to a systematic underestimation of risks relative to a daily calculation;
a 97.5% confidence level is used in calculating ES;
the length of the base liquidity horizon used by the relevant models is 10 days;

subparagraph.leadIn: an appropriate liquidity horizon applicable to individual risk factors or sets of risk factors, that—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: is capped at the maturity of the related instrument; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: is set in accordance with Table A or, with the approval of the Monetary Authority, at a higher level than that in Table A, where the increased liquidity horizon must be in the value of 20, 40, 60 or 120 days,

subparagraph.continued: is properly documented and reflected in the relevant models;

subparagraph.content: the institution is able to use a historical observation period for calculating current ES that is shorter than 12 months but not shorter than 6 months, if the Monetary Authority requests it to do so, being of the opinion that there has been a significant increase in volatility in the price of the institution’s portfolio of exposures;

data sets used for calculating current ES are updated at least once every 3 months and are reassessed whenever market prices are subject to material change, and the updating process is flexible enough to allow for more frequent updates as necessary; and
the relevant models only recognize empirical correlations of risk factors as permitted in Formula 28B of these Rules; and

paragraph.leadIn: in respect of the relevant models for NMRFs—

subparagraph.leadIn: an appropriate liquidity horizon applicable to individual risk factors or sets of risk factors, that—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: is capped at the maturity of the related instrument and floored at 20 days; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: is set in accordance with Table A or at a higher level required by the Monetary Authority,

subparagraph.continued: is properly documented and reflected in the relevant models; and

subparagraph.leadIn: the relevant models only recognize the prescribed correlations of NMRFs as permitted in Formula 28E of these Rules.
